title: Who is a better lyricist Nicki Minaj or Cardi B? - Quora

response.answer_text: While I don’t listen to either very often, I can still tell that Nicki Minaj’s lyrics are leagues above Cardi B’s. To back this up, let’s have a look at some of the lyrics from “Motorsport”, a song they both feature on with the Migos. I’m not a fan of either, so I’ll keep this unbiased. And I know some people have mentioned ghostwriters, but with nothing officially confirmed, I’m writing this answer under the assumption these are their own verses. Here are the opening lines to Cardi’s verse:  Pretty self explanatory lyrics, not much to them. The rhymes are pretty simplistic as well, but still work. There’s not too much to dissect about these bars. Now, let’s take a look at Nicki’s.  At a glance, these lyrics definitely look like they have a bit more substance to them. If you give them a read, you may be able to catch the bits of wordplay. The rhyming isn’t the most impressive (Rhyming “mouth” with “mouth”) but overall, this verse is already more interesting than Cardi’s.  These are Cardi’s next lyrics. In here, she’s discussing her relationship with Offset, one of the members of the Migos. As you can see, these lyrics convey her message quite bluntly. I mean, one line ends with “set off” and the other ends with “Offset on”… that’s about the most interesting thing here. Again, not much to dissect.  Compared to the bars from Cardi, these lines are definitely more intriguing. The “smoke with me/laced blunt” line was nice. Again, there’s not too much to the rhymes, but then again Cardi B doesn’t have that much to her’s either.  Here’s Cardi B’s next contribution. To be honest, the “Same lips” lines were the most interesting thing in this verse so far. She hasn’t really said anything too incredible that would make me want to come back for another listen.  On the other hand, here there are definitely a few things to dissect. Boosie has a signature fade but people also “catching a fade” by challenging Nicki. The rapper Lil Uzi Vert has a line about all his friends being dead, but an Uzi is also referring to a type of gun. Ricky and Lucy are characters from “I Love Lucy”. The last line is pretty self explanatory, but everything else are nice little double entendres.  Some more of Cardi’s verse here. Again, not too much here. Everything’s self-explanatory and doesn’t offer too much substance. The “Catfishing” line is the closest we get to a real dissectible and it’s not that complicated.  From Nicki Minaj’s verse, we have something a bit more interesting. I won’t waste too much time dissecting this, but the “Office worker” bar is really nice and the “Loose leaf” line is good as well. Nothing much is said on the rest of this section, but it’s still beating out Cardi.  Wrapping up Cardi B’s verse, we have these bars. For people who don’t speak Spanish, the last line is “Give me more gasoline”, as far Google translate knows. There’s not too much to say here. This verse as a whole was kinda simplistic. Let’s go ahead and move on to Nicki’s conclusion.  I’m not going too much time on these bars, but there is some nice wordplay, double entendres and the like. Once again, not much to say about the rhymes, but all in all, this is a pretty solid finish. So, overall, I think Nicki Minaj definitely outperformed Cardi B here. If you look at both verses as a whole, neither really say anything. They don’t have too much of a focus here. Nicki just said nothing in a more interesting way. I don’t think either of them are top tier lyricists by any means, but if we’re comparing them, Nicki Minaj for sure. Again, I’m not a fan of either of them. I’m judging purely off of what I’ve heard and my dissection of this song. Remember this is all opinion as well, you’re free to like whoever you want, regardless of their lyrical talent.

This seems so very obvious to me to be honest I almost feel silly for answering but not trying to make you feel bad or anything like that there is no such thing as a bad question. My answer: Nikki Minaj %100.
